subject: Politics and International Relations
statement_full_text:
Reading Cormac McCarthy's Blood Meridian, I was confronted with a series of arbitrary acts of violence, that are sanctified through self-aggrandising doctrine of Manifest Destiny. The novel identifies American exceptionalism as the ideological driver of the atrocities committed by its characters, framing brutality against indigenous peoples as a moral necessity. This prompted me to reflect on how nations use myth to legitimise conquest and sparked a deeper interest in how political ideas are constructed and weaponised. My curiosity intensified when I read Vladimir Putin's 2021 essay On the Historical Unity of Russians and Ukrainians, which echoed the same logic of entitlement I had found in McCarthy's novel. Putin dismisses Ukrainian sovereignty as a historical error showing how identity and ethnicity continue to shape international conflict. This led me to question the validity of realism as a means of explaining the actions that nations take and instead explore constructivist approaches to international relations theory that better accounted for how countries interact with their regional history and use ideology in their relations with other nations. It was through these encounters with literature and theory that I became driven to study politics and international relations.

In school i had the opportunity to be taught about human rights by law students in the ucl access to justice programme, in the module "human rights across the world" we discussed how institutions such as the un attempt to protect human rights globally, I was specifically interested by the nato intervention in Bosnia and how humanitarian crisis can cause nations to act outside out of their direct interest,as i read more about the conflict i came across John mearshimer who argued that the conflict had little security significance and that moral arguments for intervention were merely "liberal illusion", the friction between the policy suggestions of realist theory and the actions that states actually take left me sceptical of realism's place contemporary international politics.

This same scepticism resurfaced when I watched Mearsheimer's lecture "the causes and consequences of the Ukraine war" i was left unsatisfied with his assertion that Russia's invasion was an act of "offensive realism" taken in order to combat NATO's eastward expansion, certainly the war in Ukraine has come at an immense material cost to Russia while also acting as the catalyst for Finland and Sweden's entry into NATO. In looking for alternative theories for the cause of the conflict, I came across an euideas article titled "John Mearshimer's lecture on Ukraine, why he's wrong and what are the consequences",the article stresses how the monocausal reasoning that Mearsheimer deploys in his lecture completely sidesteps the domestic and ideological motivation for Putin's invasion, however what struck me the most was the observation that it is irresponsible to use ir theory in place of concrete evidence, especially when academic framing is used to legitimise aggression. Later, I read "how democracy ends" by David Runciman as research for the northeastern university essay competition, the book further emphasises the role that language and speech hold in politics, arguing that social media has made rhetoric more personal and dramatic as compresses discourse and turns it into a performance meant to generate soundbites and viral moments. In my essay I discussed how far reaching the effects of social media have been in politics: particularly its role in weakening legacy media, accelerating the spread of misinformation, creating echo chambers and facilitating stochastic terrorism . In entering this competition I learned how to conduct effective interdisciplinary research and put together creative arguments that encompass political science, media studies and sociology.

During my work experience at the October gallery I saw how artists outside of the western mainstream aren't afforded the same opportunities in creative institutions and how global cultural exchange can shape perceptions of entire people groups. This made me reflect more broadly on the politics of representation and which voices they chose to platform. Being raised by a former member of the black panther party this reflection resonated with me as conversation oppression and the right to representation were ever present in my household.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reading Cormac McCarthy's Blood Meridian, I was confronted with a series of arbitrary acts of violence, that are sanctified through self-aggrandising doctrine of Manifest Destiny. The novel identifies American exceptionalism as the ideological driver of the atrocities committed by its characters, framing brutality against indigenous peoples as a moral necessity.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This opening goes on a little bit too much considering it's not very academic in content. It's fine to use as a starter, but it's too much if it keeps going on and on. The first and second sentences are basically repetitive - you're saying you saw acts of violence and mentioned Manifest Destiny. Reduce this to its core: it identifies American exceptionalism as this thing and they're justifying it like this, then say you became interested in your subject area.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense to the core point: the novel shows American exceptionalism justifying violence, which sparked your interest in how political ideas are constructed and weaponized. Cut the repetition between first and second sentences.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My curiosity intensified when I read Vladimir Putin's 2021 essay On the Historical Unity of Russians and Ukrainians, which echoed the same logic of entitlement I had found in McCarthy's novel.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I would personally say let's not include the Putin essay. You've already included Blood Meridian which is not a direct academic text. It's not worth the risk because it's not academic first. Second, the parallels you're drawing aren't even the strongest ones you could do. It feels like you're putting it in to be attention grabbing. These tutors are just straight geeks - they don't need that sensationalism. They want deep rooted, well-developed, poignant, accurate arguments. You haven't chosen the best text to do that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut the Putin essay section entirely. If you'd made a really fantastic argument, keep it despite being risky, but you haven't. Replace with more academic content or expand existing academic sections.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This led me to question the validity of realism as a means of explaining the actions that nations take
feedback_items.your_feedback: You start discussing realism without any kind of backing into it. You have to have a little bit of a setup. I would probably just cut out that entire first paragraph section after the McCarthy part. Start with the intro of Cormac McCarthy stuff with a new reworded intro, then go straight into 'in school, I had the opportunity to...'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the transition about realism from the opening paragraph. Go directly from the McCarthy discussion to the UCL Access to Justice programme paragraph.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was specifically interested by the nato intervention in Bosnia and how humanitarian crisis can cause nations to act outside out of their direct interest,as i read more about the conflict i came across John mearshimer who argued that the conflict had little security significance and that moral arguments for intervention were merely "liberal illusion"
feedback_items.your_feedback: You've got this Mearsheimer stuff slightly wrong. What he was arguing for is not what you've got here. I believe he was arguing for more of a partition in Bosnia. You need to do two things: First, explain exactly what the NATO intervention was attempting to do, and then say what Mearsheimer believed the issue with that was.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Fact-check Mearsheimer's actual argument about Bosnia (he argued for partition). Clearly explain: 1) What NATO intervention aimed to do, 2) What Mearsheimer's specific critique was. Avoid using quotations like 'liberal illusion' unless you follow up and expand - it relies too much on the tutor having the same interpretation.

feedback_items.weak_passage: the friction between the policy suggestions of realist theory and the actions that states actually take left me sceptical of realism's place contemporary international politics
feedback_items.your_feedback: This final sentence needs to go and you need to put something else - develop that a little bit more. The context you've chosen is really interesting. Maybe you could link it to today and say what the state of Bosnia is like today, because it has gone more like Mearsheimer's way. He's predicted quite a few things. You later bring in the Ukraine stuff, and he's been talking about these issues for a while about how it's gonna happen. Develop it a bit more - you can't just drop it and leave.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace this vague conclusion with specific development: discuss Bosnia today, how Mearsheimer's predictions played out, and connect to contemporary relevance. Show what you learned specifically, not just that you're 'skeptical.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: This same scepticism resurfaced when I watched Mearsheimer's lecture
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't really want 'scepticism' here. You want to have more of a learning tone. You want to say 'this person said this, this is the process explained, and now let me give you which one I agree with more' rather than stating 'I think this is right, I think this is right' or 'I'm skeptical of this.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change tone from skepticism to learning. Instead of saying you're skeptical, explain what Mearsheimer argued, the counter-arguments, and then which perspective you found more compelling and why.

feedback_items.weak_passage: i was left unsatisfied with his assertion that Russia's invasion was an act of "offensive realism"
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't think you're actually correct here - there's a technical error. He's not saying the invasion isn't an act of offensive realism. He's saying the invasion was preventable, and he also separately talks about offensive realism. Take a beat and explain what offensive realism is first - say 'I'm really interested in the idea of offensive realism as Mearsheimer lectures about' and then explain what it is about technically and well-developed. Then explain what he thinks about why it was preventable.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: 1) First define offensive realism clearly. 2) Explain Mearsheimer's argument that the invasion was preventable (separate from offensive realism theory). 3) Then bring in someone else's view. Make sure you understand the distinction between his theory and his analysis of this specific case.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I came across an euideas article titled "John Mearshimer's lecture on Ukraine, why he's wrong and what are the consequences"
feedback_items.your_feedback: Although the general idea and theory you've brought in is fine, you can't just quote a random article. You do have to find an academic who holds that same view. Otherwise, it's just weakening your point quite a bit.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace the random euideas article with an academic source - find a scholar who makes similar arguments about Mearsheimer's analysis. This will strengthen your point significantly.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In my essay I discussed how far reaching the effects of social media have been in politics: particularly its role in weakening legacy media, accelerating the spread of misinformation, creating echo chambers and facilitating stochastic terrorism
feedback_items.your_feedback: This paragraph is very descriptive - it's just a summary of points. You've said the effects are far-reaching, it's got a role in this, that, and that. But you don't actually have any reasoning or sources or evidence or methodology for how you got to that conclusion. You need 2-3 sentences explaining how you got to that particular conclusion. Why do you believe social media is causing the acceleration of misinformation? How is it creating echo chambers? Give an example.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add 3-4 sentences of expansion: bring in a source you used and say 'according to this source, they explained it like this. And as you can see, this is exactly what's happening, which is why I concluded this.' Start with what you concluded, explain why, and say who you used to reach that conclusion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In entering this competition I learned how to conduct effective interdisciplinary research and put together creative arguments that encompass political science, media studies and sociology.
feedback_items.your_feedback: If you had just told me what the research was, what the source was, and what the argument was to get you to that conclusion, you wouldn't need this sentence. As it stands, I'm just supposed to believe you. Instead, you could actually tell me and show me exactly what you did. That'll be a lot stronger. Otherwise, I have just no idea what you're talking about here.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence. Instead, show (don't tell) by actually explaining your research methodology, sources, and arguments in the previous sentences. Let the evidence speak for itself.

feedback_items.weak_passage: During my work experience at the October gallery I saw how artists outside of the western mainstream aren't afforded the same opportunities in creative institutions
feedback_items.your_feedback: This thing about being raised by somebody who was in the Black Panther Party could potentially be a section that you replace the Putin stuff with, because it's still got that element of 'this is really something nobody else will probably be talking about.' But if you bring in an academic angle - bring in something about the party relations and the spread of ideals and how it relates to today and if there's any parallels - that would be more sensible, more academic and would resonate more with what tutors are looking for.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider moving the Black Panther Party experience to replace the Putin section. Add academic context: discuss the party's political philosophy, ideological spread, contemporary parallels. Make it analytical rather than just personal.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall, you've got really interesting points and you've done in-depth reading into a narrow range of materials, which is better than people including 15 sources shallowly. But there are factual issues/inaccuracies you need to fix. Your writing is very wordy - try to reduce word count while keeping the same content. Some sections should be swapped out. If you made these changes, you'd have a very strong statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Key fixes: 1) Fact-check Mearsheimer's arguments about Bosnia and offensive realism. 2) Make writing more concise (first/second sentences repeat). 3) Change Putin section or remove it. 4) Add methodology/reasoning/conclusion to essay section. 5) Cut 'I learned how to conduct' sentence - show don't tell. 6) Maybe bring in one more academic paper instead of random article. 7) Consider replacing Putin with developed Black Panther Party section with academic framing.
feedback_items.strong_passage: you've done in-depth reading into a narrow range of materials
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows focused, deep engagement rather than superficial breadth. This is the right approach.

subject: Economics and Geography / Development Economics
statement_full_text:
Q1
"Why do we pay for water? Why are houses so expensive? Why are some people richer than others?" As a child I asked these questions to my dad, an Economics teacher, who explained them in ways I could understand and turned them into discussions that made me feel they mattered. After he died when I was eight, I held onto those conversations. They mattered not only because they kept me close to him, but because they revealed how childhood curiosities expose deeper truths about fairness, power, and opportunity. Over time I came to realise they were not small questions, they define whose lives are valued, whose voices are heard, and how prosperity is measured.
I began to explore these questions through books that challenged conventional ways of thinking about progress and inequality. Doughnut Economics reframed prosperity within ecological ceilings and social foundations. The Spirit Level was persuasive in showing that equality improves outcomes across health and trust, though I wondered if cultural and political contexts complicate its conclusions. This led me to Post Growth, which questioned whether growth should remain central, yet I felt it underplayed urgent development needs in the global South. I realised models are never neutral; each highlights some realities while obscuring others.
I became especially drawn to the point where theory meets policy. British Columbia's carbon tax, redistributing revenue to households, showed how design can achieve equity and sustainability, while the Green New Deal's proposals for public investment showed how institutions might drive change. Together they showed that economics can be generative, not reactive. My curiosity widened to how migration reshapes communities, how trade delivers efficiency while deepening dependency, and how urban growth creates opportunity but also exclusion.
What began with my questions has grown into a determination to explore these tensions further. I want to strengthen the analytical tools I have begun to develop, to investigate how economic and geographical systems confront inequality, development, and sustainability, and to imagine fairer alternatives.
Q2
My academic interests led me to enter several essay competitions, where I explored issues from aviation expansion and climate commitments to social identity in policy. The Oxford PPE essay, on whether economic growth is compatible with climate action, forced me to grapple with whether prosperity must always be measured by growth and how climate limits challenge it. This taught me to read critically, interpret academic journals, and reference confidently. I then utilised these skills whilst completing my Geography NEA on second-home ownership and community viability in Salcombe and Hope Cove. I collected and analysed primary data, strengthening my research skills. Confronting issues of affordability and seasonal demand led me to Planetary Gentrification, which helped me situate local restructuring within global processes of displacement and uneven development.
Q3
Beyond research, I sought experiences that challenged me to communicate clearly, think under pressure, and connect theory to daily life. Preparing an assembly on consumption and waste for a primary school taught me how to simplify global issues, while politics and philosophy debating sharpened my arguments. Wanting to see how economics operates institutionally, I completed an online course in investment banking and spent a day at the Bank of England, seeing how policy and markets interact.
Volunteering in a charity shop showed how redistribution works, with goods moving from surplus to need and communities relying on reuse. It made tangible the questions I had explored about inequality and the value of goods, deepening my awareness of how inequality and sustainability are felt in communities. Such dedication developed the skills, motivation, and willingness to learn that prepare me for the perseverance demanded by university study and the ambitions I aim to pursue.

feedback_items.weak_passage: "Why do we pay for water? Why are houses so expensive? Why are some people richer than others?" As a child I asked these questions to my dad, an Economics teacher, who explained them in ways I could understand and turned them into discussions that made me feel they mattered. After he died when I was eight, I held onto those conversations.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole first paragraph is a little bit too long. Tutors are not that moved by personal stories - it's better to put something academic. Not all of these questions are good. 'Why are houses so expensive?' is relative - you've got varying prices. It's not a very nuanced question. 'Why do we pay for water?' - it's quite obvious why we pay for bottled water or house water unless you're going to the river. 'Why are some people richer than others?' has obvious answers and less obvious answers. The questions aren't good enough.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start with a better, more nuanced question. Say 'I've always wondered why X' and then say reading this book led me to find the answer or gave me insight. That would be a stronger start. If family situation needs mentioning for context, it should go in the reference.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I began to explore these questions through books that challenged conventional ways of thinking about progress and inequality.
feedback_items.your_feedback: These kind of sentences - I'm not a fan. What are you really saying? You're saying 'I've begun to explore questions through books that are thinking about other ways of progress.' You don't need to put that. I'd rather you just told me the book, told me what you learned, and then explained how it explains progress and inequality.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence. Go directly into discussing specific books and what you learned from them.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The Spirit Level was persuasive in showing that equality improves outcomes across health and trust, though I wondered if cultural and political contexts complicate its conclusions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I'd imagine so, yeah. It feels like a fairly obvious insight that cultural and political contexts would complicate conclusions about equality.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop this with specific examples of how contexts complicate conclusions, or remove this obvious observation.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I realised models are never neutral; each highlights some realities while obscuring others.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't know what that means, I'll be honest. It's not like a particularly economic technical thing, so it's a bit confusing. The logical flow in this paragraph is not the best. It talks around a lot of ideas. I prefer: A leads to B, leads to C, and this is interesting, and I'm starting to think about D. This goes here, goes there, and finishes on something vague.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: This whole section needs restructuring. Focus on one of these book ideas and expand it out, then link it to something in everyday life or current affairs. That will be a stronger paragraph.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I became especially drawn to the point where theory meets policy.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That doesn't actually mean anything. I think what you're trying to say is where we try to apply theories in policies. You don't need to say this - you can just go straight to British Columbia's carbon tax.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence and start directly with the carbon tax example.

feedback_items.weak_passage: British Columbia's carbon tax, redistributing revenue to households, showed how design can achieve equity and sustainability, while the Green New Deal's proposals for public investment showed how institutions might drive change.
feedback_items.your_feedback: There's not nearly enough detail to say this one does this and that one does that. You're jumping - you've got this tax and then this new deal, and then there's suddenly random migration, and then you talk about how trade delivers efficiency. It's like every single buzzword in the world and all of it lacks logical flow.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Pick one example and develop it thoroughly with specific details about how it works and what you learned. Don't try to cover everything superficially.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Economics can be generative, not reactive.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't know what that means.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either explain what you mean by 'generative' vs 'reactive' with specific examples, or remove this vague statement.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My curiosity widened to how migration reshapes communities, how trade delivers efficiency while deepening dependency, and how urban growth creates opportunity but also exclusion.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't know where this has come out of. This is jumping so much. When? How? When? How? It's just really lacking in logical flow and connection to what came before.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this sentence or create clear connections explaining how you moved from carbon tax/Green New Deal to thinking about migration and trade.

feedback_items.weak_passage: What began with my questions has grown into a determination to explore these tensions further. I want to strengthen the analytical tools I have begun to develop, to investigate how economic and geographical systems confront inequality, development, and sustainability, and to imagine fairer alternatives.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't know what the tensions are. This is just fluff. You don't need this - you just need to explain your other stuff better.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this concluding fluff. Use the characters to develop your actual examples and arguments earlier in the statement.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My academic interests led me to enter several essay competitions, where I explored issues from aviation expansion and climate commitments to social identity in policy.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't need to list out all the issues explored. Just cut that and start straight with 'One essay competition I entered was the Oxford PPE essay where I argued economic growth is compatible with climate change.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete the list of topics. Go directly to discussing one specific essay competition in detail.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The Oxford PPE essay, on whether economic growth is compatible with climate action, forced me to grapple with whether prosperity must always be measured by growth and how climate limits challenge it.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What was the conclusion of this essay? You haven't actually said. And you haven't told me the argument either - the reasoning of how you got to the conclusion. Are you saying it is compatible or it's not compatible, and why?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: State your actual conclusion and the reasoning/argument that led you there. What did you conclude and why?

feedback_items.weak_passage: I collected and analysed primary data, strengthening my research skills. Confronting issues of affordability and seasonal demand led me to Planetary Gentrification, which helped me situate local restructuring within global processes of displacement and uneven development.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What primary data did you collect? How is that interesting? 'Situate local restructuring within global processes of displacement' doesn't actually mean anything. You need to be really careful with your language here. Your writing style is very much like listing things out, and sometimes these ideas are out of nowhere or a bit conflicting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify what data you collected and what you found. Explain in concrete terms what you learned from Planetary Gentrification rather than using jargon.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Preparing an assembly on consumption and waste for a primary school taught me how to simplify global issues, while politics and philosophy debating sharpened my arguments. Wanting to see how economics operates institutionally, I completed an online course in investment banking and spent a day at the Bank of England
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're just going from here to here - primary school, then philosophy debates, then economics. All of this is jumping around. You need to do a little bit more development for each of these ideas rather than listing them.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop each experience with more detail (what you learned, how it connects to your interests) or cut some to make room for development of others.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Volunteering in a charity shop showed how redistribution works, with goods moving from surplus to need and communities relying on reuse. It made tangible the questions I had explored about inequality and the value of goods.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I just don't think that theory is correct actually. The connection between charity shop volunteering and understanding economic redistribution is weak.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove this or find a more accurate way to connect charity shop experience to economic concepts.

feedback_items.your_feedback: There is a serious lack of development of ideas - it reads more like a list of summary points, more overview stuff, lacking good sections. The logical flow, level of development, summary style writing, jumping about, underdeveloped theories, lack of deep insight and connection - all these things are working against you. You're clearly smart and have accomplished a lot, but the presentation needs work.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Major restructure needed: 1) Focus on 1-2 ideas and develop them really well. 2) Link to things going on right now. 3) Bring in more rigorous understanding of data collected - what's interesting? 4) Cut summary stuff and use those characters elsewhere. 5) Consider removing or significantly shortening the personal opening. 6) Actually state conclusions and arguments, not just that you 'grappled' with things.

subject: International Relations / HSPS
statement_full_text:
Question 1:
Representing the United Kingdom at LSEMUN in a debate on how to ensure humanitarian aid reaches conflict zones, I was confronted with a key question: when should moral principles override political necessity in international relations? This experience sparked a profound interest in the ways in which states uphold ethical principles whilst preserving their national sovereignty. Reading Singer's 'Famine, Affluence and Morality' convinced me of the the fact that states with the capacity to prevent human rights violations have the duty to act, yet Bull's 'The Anarchical Society' challenged this idea by arguing that the pursuit of justice can undermine world order and create greater instability. This tension is what drives my passion to understand the actions of states and their global consequences.

Question 2:
My understanding of the far-reaching socioeconomic impacts of political decisions was strengthened when I studied the Partition of India for my History A-Level. I was struck by the communal violence and malnutrition that resulted from the disruption of trade networks, and developed a commitment to addressing the human consequences of economic instability. This inspired me to explore the war in Ukraine's exacerbation of grain and fertiliser flows to sub-Saharan Africa in my data research project. My conclusion, that disrupted supply chains and fertiliser shortages have driven many in Sub-Saharan Africa further into food poverty, broadened my perspective on how conflict in one region can inadvertently exacerbate suffering in another.

Question 3:
Volunteering for Amnesty International, I gained a first-hand insight into human rights challenges worldwide. This strengthened my passion for studying government polices and how they impact vulnerable groups. As a result, I attended a talk at Chatham House on the topic of 'How are states responding to changing world order?'. An argument that particularly appealed to me was one addressing budget cuts to vital programs such as the World Food Program, and how this would impact ongoing health crises. The speaker's emphasis on the need for cross-regional approaches prompted me to consider how humanitarian and strategic aspirations can both be met through effective policy alignment. Intrigued by this argument, I explored it further in my essay for the RA Butler competition, in which I argued that international institutions are not fundamentally at odds with national sovereignty due to shared governance. Through researching World Health Organisation's 'surveillance and containment' scheme for smallpox elimination, I argued that such collaboration offers a model for future crises.

feedback_items.your_feedback: First off, it's very good. Like, it is just for what it is, it's very, very good. You get a lot of things really correctly. You've written really clearly, concisely. Language is good, the topics are good. The level of readings and lectures is very authentic. The conclusions that you draw out are really good. I'm gonna be a little bit picky with how to possibly improve this.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: This is one of the better statements seen in a while. The suggestions below are take-it-or-leave-it to strengthen it further or add content.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Reading Singer's 'Famine, Affluence and Morality' convinced me of the the fact that states with the capacity to prevent human rights violations have the duty to act, yet Bull's 'The Anarchical Society' challenged this idea by arguing that the pursuit of justice can undermine world order and create greater instability. This tension is what drives my passion to understand the actions of states and their global consequences.
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows excellent engagement with contrasting academic perspectives, demonstrates critical thinking about tensions in IR theory, and explains motivation authentically.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't know precisely how long this is (no character count included), but it feels short both in just looking at it and in some areas it's not quite enough development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider adding more content - you likely have character space available to develop ideas further.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This tension is what drives my passion to understand the actions of states and their global consequences.
feedback_items.your_feedback: It kind of leaves a little bit like, OK, so you've given me a summary of one (Singer), you give me a summary of the other (Bull), and then we're done with that. It's almost quite simple - this happened, this happens, conclusion. It's a great conclusion but it's not developed in the sense that it could go further.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: After presenting the tension between Singer and Bull, add 1-2 sentences developing this further - perhaps with a specific example of a state facing this dilemma, or discussing which approach you find more compelling in specific contexts.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My conclusion, that disrupted supply chains and fertiliser shortages have driven many in Sub-Saharan Africa further into food poverty, broadened my perspective on how conflict in one region can inadvertently exacerbate suffering in another.
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's a good conclusion, but it's not developed enough. I don't know what you mean by that exactly. It's like 'this happened, this happens, conclusion.' That's really good for exploring this one perspective of how conflict can exacerbate suffering in another region. But is that it? That's what you're left with.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop this conclusion further. What are the implications? What solutions or policy responses did you consider? What does this tell us about international systems?

feedback_items.weak_passage: Through researching World Health Organisation's 'surveillance and containment' scheme for smallpox elimination, I argued that such collaboration offers a model for future crises.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't really comment much more on that apart from saying 'I argued that such collaboration offers a model for future crises,' and that's a great conclusion. But it's not developed in the sense that I don't know what you mean by that. I don't know what kind of collaboration took place in this particular scheme. Even though tutors will probably know, you can't assume they'll have the same understanding as you about any event, reading, or conclusion.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add 2-3 sentences explaining: 1) What kind of collaboration took place in the WHO scheme? 2) What type of model are we talking about? 3) What kind of future crises? Be specific about what made this collaboration successful and how it could apply.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Since you're applying to Cambridge for HSPS (not just IR at other universities), there isn't so much range here. It's mainly about politics and international relations. It's not quite leaning enough into sociology or anthropology or any of the other topics offered in HSPS. One way to strengthen this would be to add another section for one of those - something quite high level, maybe university reading level, that could draw out elements of what you've already spoken about.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: For HSPS at Cambridge specifically, consider adding a section covering sociology or anthropology. Use remaining characters to either: 1) Develop all three existing ideas a bit more, OR 2) Add another section from a different HSPS area you haven't yet covered (sociology/anthropology/psychology).

feedback_items.your_feedback: The actual topics and what you've done are all perfectly good. I wouldn't take anything out. I would just add. You're a good writer. Any of these changes would take this from being a very good statement to an excellent one.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Two options for using remaining characters: 1) Develop all three existing sections more (add specifics, examples, implications). 2) Add a new section covering sociology/anthropology for HSPS breadth. Both approaches would strengthen the statement.
feedback_items.strong_passage: My understanding of the far-reaching socioeconomic impacts of political decisions was strengthened when I studied the Partition of India for my History A-Level. I was struck by the communal violence and malnutrition that resulted from the disruption of trade networks, and developed a commitment to addressing the human consequences of economic instability.
feedback_items.why_strong: Makes a strong connection between historical study and contemporary research interests. Shows how academic study shaped personal commitment to the field.

subject: Computer Science
statement_full_text:
Personal Statement

Q1.

The ability to create, to transform abstract thoughts, ideas, and dreams into realities through computer science, is what draws me to the subject. From programs that guided a spacecraft thousands of miles to the moon autonomously, to algorithms that govern the global financial system, from supercomputers mapping billions of base pairs of human DNA, to particles colliding near the speed of light with results analyzed at the nanoscale. The fact that the entirety of the world runs on zeros and ones, controlled by incredibly complex mathematical equations, is something I find endlessly fascinating and impossible to ignore.

Equally compelling to me is the problem solving nature of computer science. The ability to find a complex problem and decompose it into simple components, creating robust solutions that work across different iterations of the problem in a manner that is most efficient

(.Possible add something more)

Q2

Studying GCSE and Higher Computing has given me a strong foundation in procedural programming, algorithm design and data structures alongside skills like abstraction, decomposition and problem solving. Higher Chemistry and Personal Statement1Higher Physics have also helped me develop my application of knowledge into new and abstract situations.

In my younger years, partaking in a robotics class using LEGO Mindstorms EV3, introduced the concept of procedural programming and the importance of the order in which the code is written in interpreted languages, whilst my experience writing code on Roblox also introduced me to object-oriented programming and served as a foundation for using languages such as Java as well as videogame programming using Unity and Roblox Studio.

Beyond the academic scene, programmes like the Future Leaders Programme aswell as student leadership and prom committee in my previous school helped me develop soft skills such as time management, communication and leadership, organising and presenting ideas within deadlines, skills necessary in software development roles. Following this, I created a local Whatsapp-based revision group for my peers during GCSEs to share resources whilst improving on my own knowledge by providing help. This experience further developed my organisation, leadership and time management skills

Q3

Outside my education, I explored the mathematical aspects of computing by enrolling in the Scottish maths challenge. Attaining silver, the experience allowed me to combine both my mathematical problem solving skills with my programming abilities to abstract problem solving scenarios, writing algorithms that iterate through combinatorics that exceeded 100,000 permutations with time complexities of O(n), Using a slower language like Python taught me the importance of the algorithmic efficiency needed to reduce the conditions to a manageable time frame as well as the restrictions programming languages face in real world applications. The experience further gave me the opportunity, during the award ceremony, to attend a lecture about networking and using matrices to find the degree of nodes, an experience which deepened my interest in learning about linear algebra and its application in computing and AI.

To explore my interest in the cyber security aspect of computing I partook in the CyberFirst national competition, where I scored 3rd place regionally, Personal Statement2developing skills such as web security, packet sniffing, OSINT and cryptography, where I reverse engineered an RSA encryption using Python as well as web crawlers to exploit vulnerabilities in web pages. This experience developed my interest in OSINT and cryptography, which led me to take several courses on the TryHackMe program which improved my understanding of offensive and defensive security.

In my spare time, I've undertaken a personal project using the framework Customtkinter to design a movie app, similar to IMDB, integrated with a backend database, allowing for custom user based interfaces as well as search and filtering systems. As something I plan to develop further as my Advanced Higher computing project, this project gave me a practical experience in full stack development from frameworks and UI/UX development to database management, creating real software and catering to user needs.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The ability to create, to transform abstract thoughts, ideas, and dreams into realities through computer science, is what draws me to the subject.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The first sentence is vague. You could really apply that to pretty much any subject. It doesn't help to bring out any insight about what you think about computer science.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut this sentence and start with a specific example or concept from computer science that genuinely interests you.

feedback_items.weak_passage: From programs that guided a spacecraft thousands of miles to the moon autonomously, to algorithms that govern the global financial system, from supercomputers mapping billions of base pairs of human DNA, to particles colliding near the speed of light with results analyzed at the nanoscale.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole list - surprisingly a lot of people do it, but it's not a very strong thing to do. I would cut the first sentence and the third sentence as well ('the fact that the entirety of the world runs on zeros and ones' - that's just so general, so vague). Cut that whole thing and focus on ONE of the points you've mentioned.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose one example (e.g., programs guiding spacecraft to the moon). Develop that point and say how is that done? Mention some technical theory behind it and say 'this is just one of the things that really interests me about computer science.' That would be perfect.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The fact that the entirety of the world runs on zeros and ones, controlled by incredibly complex mathematical equations, is something I find endlessly fascinating and impossible to ignore.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Again, that's just so general, so vague. Cut this.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence entirely.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Equally compelling to me is the problem solving nature of computer science. The ability to find a complex problem and decompose it into simple components, creating robust solutions that work across different iterations of the problem in a manner that is most efficient
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is problematic because firstly, it can be applied to lots of different subjects. It's not that specific. And also, it's very general, very vague, and really doesn't tell me anything about your particular understanding of computer science.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Scrap this. Start with one of the points in current affairs or something you've seen, go into detail, and that would be a very strong start.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Studying GCSE and Higher Computing has given me a strong foundation in procedural programming, algorithm design and data structures alongside skills like abstraction, decomposition and problem solving.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Do not list out your skills like this. The fact that you've done those subjects, they will know what you've done in those subjects. There's no point you repeating it. It really doesn't tell you anything. What you need to provide is evidence that you can do more than just what is inside your GCSE and A Level.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence. Focus on what you've done BEYOND the curriculum.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Higher Chemistry and Personal Statement1Higher Physics have also helped me develop my application of knowledge into new and abstract situations.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I wouldn't even bother mentioning chemistry and physics. If you want to mention something about your subjects, at least tell me what these new and abstract situations are, and also how it develops your knowledge, because without that, it's a little bit meaningless.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this sentence OR specify exactly what 'new and abstract situations' you mean and how chemistry/physics helped with computer science.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In my younger years, partaking in a robotics class using LEGO Mindstorms EV3, introduced the concept of procedural programming and the importance of the order in which the code is written in interpreted languages, whilst my experience writing code on Roblox also introduced me to object-oriented programming
feedback_items.your_feedback: This Lego Mindstorms and Roblox stuff has the potential to be really interesting. It's just that you don't expand enough. I want to know: what did you build? Give me some real detail about what you actually did. Tell me the most complex thing you did, and whether that led you to another book or another lecture. Filler sentences like 'in my younger years' - just cut out anything like that. It doesn't add any value.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove 'in my younger years.' Expand this paragraph significantly: What specific projects did you build? What was the most complex element? What challenges did you face? Did this lead you to further reading or resources?

feedback_items.weak_passage: Beyond the academic scene, programmes like the Future Leaders Programme aswell as student leadership and prom committee in my previous school helped me develop soft skills such as time management, communication and leadership, organising and presenting ideas within deadlines, skills necessary in software development roles. Following this, I created a local Whatsapp-based revision group for my peers during GCSEs to share resources whilst improving on my own knowledge by providing help. This experience further developed my organisation, leadership and time management skills
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is another example of you just listing out skills that have to be inferred by tutors. If you did the Future Leaders programme, tell me what did you do on that - is there anything interesting that came about that's linked to your computer science studies? All of this stuff you can just condense. It's good to mention these things, but turn it into one sentence: 'outside my academics, I also do this, this and this, full stop.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense all extracurriculars to ONE sentence. Use the saved space to develop technical content. If mentioning Future Leaders, link it specifically to computer science.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Outside my education, I explored
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't say stuff like 'outside my education' - that's filler. Just start with 'I explored the mathematical aspects of computing by enrolling in this challenge.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete 'Outside my education' and similar filler phrases.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The experience allowed me to combine both my mathematical problem solving skills with my programming abilities
feedback_items.your_feedback: Rather than telling me you combined it, just tell me a little bit more. Cut that bit out and then just talk more about these algorithms that you worked with. This combinatorics thing sounds really interesting - can you develop that point more? This Python thing sounds really interesting - can you develop that more?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete 'the experience allowed me to combine...' Instead, dive directly into technical details about the algorithms, combinatorics, and Python challenges.

feedback_items.weak_passage: writing algorithms that iterate through combinatorics that exceeded 100,000 permutations with time complexities of O(n), Using a slower language like Python taught me the importance of the algorithmic efficiency
feedback_items.your_feedback: Good content choice but lacking in level of detail. What did you do? How did you do it? What challenges did you run across? How did you get over that? What would you like to do at university that connects to that? What are you looking forward to doing? When talking about restrictions programming languages face in real world applications, tell me what they are, what are the applications you would want to do, what are the restrictions?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop with: specific challenges you faced, how you overcame them, what you learned about algorithm efficiency, what you want to explore at university. Be specific about real-world applications and restrictions.
feedback_items.strong_passage: writing algorithms that iterate through combinatorics that exceeded 100,000 permutations with time complexities of O(n)
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows specific technical detail and complexity of work undertaken.

feedback_items.weak_passage: to attend a lecture about networking and using matrices to find the degree of nodes
feedback_items.your_feedback: You just touch upon it - 'we can use matrices to find degree of nodes.' How? What would you do with that? It obviously deepens your interest in learning, but can you tell me its relevance and what you really take out of it?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain how matrices are used to find degree of nodes, what this means, and why it's relevant to your interests in computing and AI.

feedback_items.weak_passage: developing skills such as web security, packet sniffing, OSINT and cryptography, where I reverse engineered an RSA encryption using Python as well as web crawlers to exploit vulnerabilities
feedback_items.your_feedback: I just want to know more. You go into some level of detail. Can you go into more detail? You're gonna need to expand on these parts because the other parts should be cut down. Again, if you mention you did those TryHackMe programmes, maybe mention one interesting problem that you came across or something that you learned there.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand significantly on RSA encryption reverse engineering - how did you do it? What was challenging? For TryHackMe, give a specific example of an interesting problem or technique you learned.
feedback_items.strong_passage: I reverse engineered an RSA encryption using Python as well as web crawlers to exploit vulnerabilities in web pages
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows specific technical achievement with concrete detail.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I've undertaken a personal project using the framework Customtkinter to design a movie app, similar to IMDB, integrated with a backend database, allowing for custom user based interfaces as well as search and filtering systems.
feedback_items.your_feedback: It reads a little bit too basic to just say it allows custom user-based interfaces and search systems. Maybe you could say: I started with this, but what I would eventually like to develop is something else. Or talk about a new development in programming and how databases have developed, and what you would like to learn about and what the challenges are. Something from current affairs would be good if you can bring in something that's happened recently, especially with all these developments in AI and programming languages.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of just describing what the app does, discuss: technical challenges you faced, what you want to add next, recent developments in full-stack/database technology, how AI might integrate. Connect to broader trends.

feedback_items.weak_passage: this project gave me a practical experience in full stack development from frameworks and UI/UX development to database management, creating real software and catering to user needs.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't like this last sentence because you're just listing out things that you're gonna maybe do. Just by the nature of you doing that project, they're gonna assume you have some level of understanding. It's much better to focus on your experience with ONE of these things in depth.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this list. Instead, focus on one aspect of the project (e.g., database management challenges, UI/UX decisions, framework choice) and explain it in technical depth.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You've got good content, you've done a lot of really interesting things. You're just not presenting yourself the best way. You need to cut out filler stuff and descriptions of skills we already know you have. You need to develop these ideas more so I know: what you did, what you learned from it, what the challenges are, how this links to what you want to do at university.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Major revisions: 1) Cut entire Q1 opening and replace with one specific developed example. 2) Delete all skill lists (GCSE content, soft skills, 'full stack development'). 3) Massively expand technical sections: Scottish Maths Challenge (algorithms/combinatorics), CyberFirst (RSA encryption), personal project (specific technical challenges). 4) Add: what challenges you faced, how you overcame them, what you want to study at university, connections to current developments in CS/AI.

subject: Biochemistry
statement_full_text:
Proteins underpin life: enzymes catalyse reactions in seconds, antibodies defend us and membrane proteins control transport. Their variety captivated me, but what stood out most was that in every protein, structure dictated function.
After hearing about my teacher's experience with sickle cell anaemia, I learnt how a single residue substitution from glutamic acid to valine alters the structure of haemoglobin and causes agglutination. I was curious how such a life-threatening disease could arise from such a small mutation. Suzanne Clancy's article 'Genetic Mutation' showed me that this stems from just one base substitution  adenine to thymine  in the beta globin gene. This idea that a single missense mutation can drastically affect quality of life, disproportionately impacting people of African and Caribbean heritage, drives my ambition to research into genetic disease.
My fascination with proteins grew at Balliol College's Try Before You Buy Day, where I explored how protein stability guides vaccine design. I learnt how six stabilising proline substitutions were engineered into the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein to create the HexaPro variant. This prevents the protein from prematurely collapsing into its post-fusion state, making it more effective as a vaccine antigen. I wondered why alternatives, like disulphide bonds, weren't used instead, only to find that misplaced disulphide bonds risk misfolding and aggregation, impairing the spike protein's trimeric assembly. Seeing how we can understand and manipulate protein structure and conformational dynamics to further public health reinforced my desire to study biochemistry.
Studying shapes of molecules in A-level Chemistry led to an interest in chirality, which I deepened at a University of Birmingham lecture on enantiomers. It amazed me that thalidomide's two stereoisomers, despite having identical connectivity, have completely different effects.
Wanting to learn more about drug action, I took an OpenLearn course on aspirin, learning how it inhibits COX enzymes by acetylation, preventing prostaglandin production. Linking my knowledge of enzyme inhibition and bonding, I understood how the strength of the covalent bond prolongs the drug's effect. This revealed how knowledge of molecular structure can be harnessed to improve lives through pharmacology.
A-level Biology has inspired my pursuit of biochemistry. I was intrigued by how chromosomal DNA encodes traits. I enjoyed exploring X-linked traits through Morgan's fruit fly experiments on eye colour at a Cambridge masterclass. Through this I questioned why sex chromosome aneuploidies are more tolerated than autosomal ones. I discovered the role of X-inactivation in balancing gene dosage between sexes, a mechanism absent in autosomes.
During the UNIQ Summer School, I developed my interest in genetics further through lab workshops. Using CRISPR-Cas9 and recombination, I inserted a stop codon in the lacZ gene, with blue-white screening confirming inhibition of beta-galactosidase production. Practising aseptic techniques and micropipetting gave me insight into real research, while seeing gene-editing first-hand excited me about CRISPR's potential to treat sickle cell anaemia. I later learnt how base-editing variants offer more control over gene editing without cutting DNA, making it a safer option. The ethical dilemmas, discussed by Nessa Carey on The Naked Scientists, showed me how science and society must advance together.
Beyond academics, leading debate sessions, co-running my school's ACS and balancing a part-time job have enhanced my teamwork, leadership and time-management, vital for collaborative research. My passion for linguistics will also be useful for scientific communication.
For me, the beauty of Biochemistry lies in its molecules. Their miniscule size yet immense power is the source of the subject's potential. I'm eager to study them in depth and use that knowledge to contribute to meaningful scientific progress.

feedback_items.your_feedback: As an overall review, it's not bad for sure. If you kept it as is, I don't think this is going to be a red flag or something that stops you from getting into top universities. In terms of content and quality, you'd be definitely top 25% of similar people applying. It doesn't blow me away, but you've done a good job overall. Bear in mind this is just my opinion.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Statement is solid but could be elevated from 'very good' to 'excellent' with refinements below.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Proteins underpin life: enzymes catalyse reactions in seconds, antibodies defend us and membrane proteins control transport. Their variety captivated me, but what stood out most was that in every protein, structure dictated function.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is quite meaningless. It's kind of like putting poetry in something scientific. You're showing your ambition and passion enough, so would I personally include that in a highly academic personal statement? No, probably not. The number of times I've seen this exact kind of sentence combination - it's in so many different things. You think it shows your personal interest, but it's not unique.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete or significantly condense this opening. Start with the sickle cell paragraph which is much stronger and more specific.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This paragraph about sickle cell anaemia is strong. You explained what you did very well, explained the science well, talked about the article, and it drives your ambition. This ties in quite nicely.
feedback_items.strong_passage: After hearing about my teacher's experience with sickle cell anaemia, I learnt how a single residue substitution from glutamic acid to valine alters the structure of haemoglobin and causes agglutination. I was curious how such a life-threatening disease could arise from such a small mutation. Suzanne Clancy's article 'Genetic Mutation' showed me that this stems from just one base substitution  adenine to thymine  in the beta globin gene. This idea that a single missense mutation can drastically affect quality of life, disproportionately impacting people of African and Caribbean heritage, drives my ambition to research into genetic disease.
feedback_items.why_strong: Well-developed, specific scientific detail, clear progression from curiosity to understanding, authentic motivation.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This paragraph about protein fascination at Balliol is also decent. You wondered why this doesn't work, and then seeing how we can understand - this section is good.
feedback_items.strong_passage: My fascination with proteins grew at Balliol College's Try Before You Buy Day, where I explored how protein stability guides vaccine design. I learnt how six stabilising proline substitutions were engineered into the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein to create the HexaPro variant. This prevents the protein from prematurely collapsing into its post-fusion state, making it more effective as a vaccine antigen. I wondered why alternatives, like disulphide bonds, weren't used instead, only to find that misplaced disulphide bonds risk misfolding and aggregation, impairing the spike protein's trimeric assembly.
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows intellectual curiosity (asking 'why not alternatives?'), technical understanding, and independent thinking beyond what was presented.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Studying shapes of molecules in A-level Chemistry led to an interest in chirality, which I deepened at a University of Birmingham lecture on enantiomers. It amazed me that thalidomide's two stereoisomers, despite having identical connectivity, have completely different effects.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This section is quite a lot weaker comparatively. You watched this lecture and were amazed by this one thing. It kind of reads like a summary - 'OK, I've ticked this off now. I'm including this so you know I did this lecture.' It doesn't show that leveling of understanding or how it ties into your specific authentic understanding. Anybody who'd attended the lecture could say the same thing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop this section significantly. What specifically about chirality interests you in biochemistry? How does this connect to proteins or drug design? What questions did it raise? What did you explore further?

feedback_items.weak_passage: Wanting to learn more about drug action, I took an OpenLearn course on aspirin, learning how it inhibits COX enzymes by acetylation, preventing prostaglandin production. Linking my knowledge of enzyme inhibition and bonding, I understood how the strength of the covalent bond prolongs the drug's effect. This revealed how knowledge of molecular structure can be harnessed to improve lives through pharmacology.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Same problem here. You understood the strength of the covalent bond prolongs the drug's effect, and then you're interested in how this can improve lives. It reads a little bit as a tick - 'now I've included this, now I understand the impacts this can have.' Could this work better? Maybe. It's not bad, but comparatively weaker than your strong paragraphs.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop this more (what was surprising? what did you investigate further? how does aspirin compare to other NSAIDs?) or consider removing to give more space to stronger sections.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I enjoyed exploring X-linked traits through Morgan's fruit fly experiments on eye colour at a Cambridge masterclass. Through this I questioned why sex chromosome aneuploidies are more tolerated than autosomal ones. I discovered the role of X-inactivation in balancing gene dosage between sexes, a mechanism absent in autosomes.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You enjoyed exploring excellent traits through this thing at Cambridge masterclass, and then you questioned this one thing, you discovered this one thing. Like, all three of these weaker paragraphs are just comparative to the others - a lot weaker. If you were able to cut some of this other stuff, you could potentially develop those a little bit more.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop further: What was it about Morgan's experiments that sparked the question? What did you read to understand X-inactivation better? How does this connect to your interest in genetic disease?

feedback_items.your_feedback: This paragraph about UNIQ Summer School is very strong. You explained what you did very well using CRISPR, linked the lab techniques you learned, connected to treating sickle cell anaemia, then developed with base-editing variants and brought in ethics. This paragraph is very strong and well developed.
feedback_items.strong_passage: During the UNIQ Summer School, I developed my interest in genetics further through lab workshops. Using CRISPR-Cas9 and recombination, I inserted a stop codon in the lacZ gene, with blue-white screening confirming inhibition of beta-galactosidase production. Practising aseptic techniques and micropipetting gave me insight into real research, while seeing gene-editing first-hand excited me about CRISPR's potential to treat sickle cell anaemia. I later learnt how base-editing variants offer more control over gene editing without cutting DNA, making it a safer option. The ethical dilemmas, discussed by Nessa Carey on The Naked Scientists, showed me how science and society must advance together.
feedback_items.why_strong: Excellent development: specific technical detail, connects to earlier themes (sickle cell), shows continued learning beyond the workshop, brings in ethics naturally.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Beyond academics, leading debate sessions, co-running my school's ACS and balancing a part-time job have enhanced my teamwork, leadership and time-management, vital for collaborative research. My passion for linguistics will also be useful for scientific communication.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Am I a fan of including this part-time job and listing teamwork, leadership, time management? Not particularly. But I know you feel you have to have something like that. I'd prefer you just listed the things you did rather than saying 'I'm really good at teamwork.' But that's your choice.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider just listing activities in one sentence: 'Beyond academics, I lead debate sessions, co-run my school's ACS, and work part-time.' Remove the skills list or keep it very brief.

feedback_items.weak_passage: For me, the beauty of Biochemistry lies in its molecules. Their miniscule size yet immense power is the source of the subject's potential. I'm eager to study them in depth and use that knowledge to contribute to meaningful scientific progress.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This very last paragraph does the same thing as the first paragraph. That's like 8 lines you've given to basically saying 'the beauty of biochemistry lies in its molecules. Like, what does that mean? Minuscule size, immense power as a source of the subject's potential - I know you probably think the tutors gonna say 'oh wow, a fellow passionate biochemist.' They're just not gonna think that way. You could really save yourself those eight lines and use that elsewhere.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete this entire conclusion. Use those characters to develop the weaker middle paragraphs (chirality, aspirin, X-inactivation).

feedback_items.your_feedback: You're not the most efficient writer. Your writing is very lengthy and almost quite difficult to follow at times because you're including so many clauses. Example: 'The idea that a single missense mutation can drastically affect quality of life, disproportionately impacting people of African and Caribbean heritage, drives my ambition to research into genetic research' - that's not a very clean sentence. You do that at quite a lot of different points.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Try this exercise: take the statement and try to reduce word count while keeping exactly the same content. This will help you identify inefficient writing. You're over character count, and this exercise will help you both stay within limits and improve clarity. If you kept the same content but made it really dense and well-written, it would be fantastic.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I think you're very close to this being an exceptional personal statement, because you've done everything correctly and your level of knowledge is good and you're clearly into the subject. I think it's just lacking that kind of nuance, that sort of final refinement. The content you've chosen is good, the range of supercurriculars is good. Your stronger paragraphs (sickle cell, Balliol proteins, UNIQ) are excellent. The weaker ones (chirality, aspirin, X-inactivation) need more development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Key improvements: 1) Delete opening and closing 'poetry' paragraphs (save ~8 lines each). 2) Work on concise writing throughout - reduce word count while keeping meaning. 3) Use saved characters to develop the three weaker middle paragraphs significantly. 4) Consider condensing extracurricular paragraph to one sentence. If you made these changes, this would go from very good to exceptional.
